We return to Washington this week to an uncertain future for the Affordable Care Act. After 10 days of being home, I am more unsettled, worried and focused than ever on the responsibility we as elected officials have to our constituents.  So many of you shared stories with me about how the ACA has positively impacted your life, and I thank you. This piece I wrote for the Detroit Free Press details some of those stories and the consistent message I heard from constituents while I was home: Don't let them take my health care away.   We will continue to lift up your stories as we fight to protect the care that millions in Michigan and across the country depend upon. I will work with anyone, most assuredly across the aisle, to improve the ACA for every American, but I won't vote for a bad bill. Some things in life are worth fighting for. This is a fight that defines the heart and soul of who we are as Americans. Please read and share. #ProtectOurCare

Recently, my colleagues and I wrote U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin strongly opposing proposed cuts to critical unemployment benefits for disabled veterans. The President's 2018 budget proposal would have eliminated Individual Unemployability (IU) benefits, which more than 12,300 retirement-age veterans in Michigan - who have been unable to find work as a result of a service-related disability - rely on as an economic lifeline.   In response to our letter Secretary Shulkin said that after careful consideration, he determined that he could not support a policy that has the potential to cause significant financial harm to veterans. This is a positive step in keeping our most fundamental promise to the brave men and women who served our country. We must continue to build on progress in our states to end veteran homelessness and poverty, not undermine these critical efforts.

As you may have heard, today is a major day of action in support of #NetNeutrality. Net neutrality is about protecting fairness, openness, and competition. It protects consumers by ensuring broadband providers do not block or slow down websites and protects small businesses and innovators by ensuring they have a level playing field online. We must make our voices heard and ensure the Internet continues to be free and open for all.

No one should ever live in fear for their life or safety because of domestic violence. Today, I was proud to join my colleague Rep. Daniel M. Donovan to introduce the bipartisan Zero Tolerance for Domestic Abusers Act, legislation that protects survivors of dating violence and stalking from gun violence.   In communities across the country, too many families experience senseless tragedies that could have been prevented. This bipartisan bill makes commonsense updates to our laws to ensure women and families are protected -- and ultimately save lives.

The cosmetic changes made to the Senate #ACA repeal bill do nothing to change the fact that this legislation is fundamentally devastating for working families, seniors, children and the most vulnerable. The bill will still strip coverage from millions of Americans, end Healthy Michigan, gut protections for those with pre-existing conditions, and slash critical Medicaid funding for children and seniors with long-term care needs. Add to this the devastating Cruz amendment, which analysts predict would send insurance markets into a ‘death spiral,’ and this bill represents a clear threat to the health and well-being of American families and our economy.   It’s time for Republicans to work with Democrats in a bipartisan manner to bring down costs and improve health care for every American. #ProtectOurCare

We have a crisis of confidence in our drinking water systems in this country, and consumers deserve clear and immediate notification and transparency when it comes to water quality. In Michigan, where the Flint water crisis still remains in our hearts and minds, we know the importance of this more than most.   This week, I introduced legislation that would make consumer confidence reports on drinking water quality more frequent and easier for every American to understand.  With 90 percent of Americans receiving their drinking water from a public drinking water system, it is our collective responsibility to provide strong funding for modernization and continue to find effective ways to keep the public informed on the quality of their drinking water. This should be an important piece of the puzzle as we continue to advance legislation in the Energy & Commerce Committee that will improve drinking water systems in this country and help prevent future drinking water crises. More information→bit.ly/2urQE7X

It was an honor to help present the family of Corporal Rupert Scheer, a World War I veteran, with a Purple Heart in recognition of his service and sacrifice in the U.S. Marine Corps. It is because of individuals like Corporal Scheer, who served this country with courage, valor and distinction, that we remain the land of the free and home of the brave. This well deserved award helps to ensure that Rupert Scheer's contributions to our country are properly honored.

In states like Michigan, where the auto industry is the backbone of our economy, decades of bad trade deals have hollowed out our manufacturing base and cost too many hardworking Americans the opportunity to earn a decent living. That’s why, when President Trump made big promises on NAFTA renegotiations during the campaign – to reduce our trade deficit and create U.S. manufacturing jobs – his message resonated with the people I represent.  It’s now time to back up that talk with action. Like the original notice to Congress in May, the administration's NAFTA negotiating objectives released today are vague, short on details and fail to outline how this renegotiation would raise wages or create new American jobs.   This agreement must be negotiated in a way that puts working Americans first, and transparency is critical. I will be working with my colleagues to ensure the American people know what is being negotiated and can determine how these policies will impact their families. I urge the administration to work with Congress on a real game plan that will make our trade deals better for working men and women and uphold President Trump’s promise to the people I represent.

The Senate’s latest effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act collapsed because millions of Americans made their voices heard. With this devastating proposal off the table, it’s now time for Republicans to work with Democrats in a serious and bipartisan manner to update and improve the ACA for every American.    Repealing the ACA without a replacement is not the answer. This irresponsible proposal would send insurance markets into turmoil and result in 32 million Americans losing their health care. Similarly, continuing to undermine the Affordable Care Act and push for its failure is not a plan; it’s a non-starter.   This is not about politics. This is about real people’s lives. It is time to fix what we all know doesn’t work in the ACA and give people the peace of mind that the provisions that do work – the provisions they depend upon – will be protected. People deserve to know once and for all that their health care will be there, that Medicaid will be protected and pre-existing conditions will continue to be covered. We have a responsibility to act in the best interest of the American people. It’s time to work together to improve health care and give the American people the certainty they deserve.

Today the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee voted unanimously to advance bipartisan draft legislation to support the development and deployment of automated vehicles. With this legislation, we have the opportunity to reshape American manufacturing for decades to come.   The fact is, if we want the next great wave of manufacturing and R&D to take place in this country as opposed to overseas, then we need to have a strong but flexible regulatory framework for automated vehicles that always puts safety first. It is also clear that every Member, Democrats and Republicans, deeply care about cybersecurity and privacy. It is critical we get this right, and I want to thank Chairman Bob Latta, as well as Ranking Members Jan Schakowsky and Frank Pallone Jr. for their hard work on this bipartisan legislation.   Automated vehicles are going to be developed – the only question is where it will happen first. We want the United States to remain in the driver’s seat, and today’s draft bill is a major step in the right direction. I look forward to continuing our work toward introducing bipartisan, consensus legislation.

For too long, U.S. trade deals have been negotiated behind closed doors without input from the public.   Today, I introduced the Promoting Transparency in Trade Act that will shine a light on trade negotiations and bring clarity to the process, which is currently off limits to the American people. This will ensure the public – not just corporations and special interests – have a seat at the table on policies that impact their lives and economic well-being.   The American people deserve to have a voice in trade agreements being negotiated on their behalf.

Today, I led a letter to Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, signed by 21 colleagues, urging him to reconsider his decision to shut down the State Department's office for cyber issues, which would leave the U.S. as the only major country without a cybersecurity diplomat.   Cybersecurity is one area where bipartisan agreements on policy and strategy still exist. At a time when the world is more interconnected than ever and we face constant cyber threats from state actors, it is vital that we retain a high-level diplomatic role to report directly to the Secretary on global cybersecurity. Read the letter here→http://bit.ly/2vt2fRy

Since becoming a member of Congress, I have felt the frustration, anger and fear of many in my district. Too many Americans feel that the rules are rigged against them. They are working harder than ever – their wages are stagnant, their pensions are in jeopardy, college costs are skyrocketing, and the promise of a secure and dignified retirement is slipping away. Put simply, for too many Americans, the economy isn’t working the way it should.   Over the last several months, Democrats in the House and Senate have acknowledged the need to come together from the diverse, dynamic regions we represent to create a plan - an economic agenda - to improve the lives of the hardworking men and women across the country.    Today, Democrats began the process of putting forward an agenda to tackle the problems many continue to face. The plan, called #ABetterDeal, targets the fundamental challenges working families deal with every day by raising wages, creating good-paying jobs, fighting back against outsourcing, lowering the cost of living, reducing the price of prescription drugs and giving working Americans the tools to succeed in the 21st Century. You can read the specifics by going to: http://bit.ly/2v0GHP8.   Our job is to support hardworking men and women who have been left out and left behind. We have a responsibility as elected officials to work to help create good-paying jobs, opportunity and sustained economic growth. We all must work together to achieve that.

Twenty-seven years ago today, the Americans with Disabilities Act was signed into law, marking one of the most important civil rights victories of our time. With this landmark law, our country committed to prohibiting discrimination against individuals with disabilities and to actively work toward a future where all are given equal opportunity and access to the workplace, schools, transportation, and public areas.   Today, as we reflect on the promise and success of the ADA and the committed men and women who made its passage possible, we recommit ourselves to ensuring that every American has the opportunity to live both independently and with dignity, including access to quality affordable health care. Enshrined in the ADA is the promise of fairness, opportunity, and equal opportunity for all Americans, and we must work together to break down the barriers that still exist. #ADA27

Medicare provides critical health coverage to millions of beneficiaries, but there are serious gaps in coverage which exist. Today, I introduced the Medicare Hearing Aid Coverage Act, which would expand Medicare to cover hearing aids for beneficiaries.  Hearing loss is the third most prevalent chronic condition in the United States, but today an estimated 70 percent of Americans with hearing problems between the ages of 65 and 84 are not using hearing aids, often because they cannot afford them. This can lead to isolation, depression, and as a growing number of studies have documented, the development of Alzheimer’s and dementia. This legislation will help address this growing problem. No one should feel isolated, confused or shutout from the world because they cannot afford the treatment they need.

While most people think of nuts-and-bolts manufacturing when they think of Detroit, the story of our domestic auto industry is really the story of American innovation. Companies that innovated survived and those that didn’t fell by the wayside. The next chapter of American innovation is here with the development of self-driving cars.   The challenge is for the United States to figure out how we can remain at the forefront of innovation and technology in the world and build a regulatory framework that first and foremost protects consumers, but is also flexible and can keep up with the pace of rapidly changing technology. It is imperative that we get this right. I am pleased that today, the House Energy and Commerce Committee unanimously approved bipartisan automated vehicle legislation that brings us one step closer to accomplishing that goal.

Our veterans deserve our gratitude and the best care possible. They should also never have to face treatment or hospital stays without the support of their loved ones by their sides. Pleased the House approved an amendment I cosponsored with my friend Congressman John K. Delaney to increase funding for Fisher House, which provides a home away from home for families of veterans who are receiving treatment at military and VA medical centers so they can stay together throughout the treatment process and ease the road to recovery.

On this day in 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed into law Medicare and Medicaid. A few days earlier @JohnDingell presided over the House of Representatives during its passage, and the gavel that he used sits proudly in my office to this day. 52 years later, these bedrock programs remain part of the fabric of our country. They continue to provide vital coverage to millions of Americans and make good on the promise we make to our seniors that after a lifetime of hard work they can retire with security, dignity and quality, affordable health care. I’m so proud of the work that John and his father did to establish these vital programs, and pledge to continue their work in upholding and strengthening Medicare and Medicaid as our population ages. It is critical that we work together to protect these programs and the security they provide to seniors and the most vulnerable Americans.

The hardworking men and women at the EPA facilities in Ann Arbor and Grosse Ile play a vital role in protecting our communities – whether it’s reducing vehicle emissions and keeping the U.S. at the forefront of innovation or cleaning up toxic spills that threaten the health of our families and environment. We cannot afford to lose these jobs or halt the critical work taking place in these areas.   With proposed budget cuts threatening to shutter EPA facilities across the country, I introduced legislation that would prevent the closure of any EPA regional or program office, including the EPA Vehicle Lab in Ann Arbor and the Large Lakes Research Station office on Grosse Ile. This legislation will ensure that this important work continues in Michigan and at EPA offices across the country, where dedicated scientists, engineers and public servants are working every day to protect the air we breathe and the water we drink now and for the future. This must remain a top priority.

Today, as part of #StartupDay Across America, I visited local entrepreneurs at Ann Arbor SPARK and took a walking tour of local startup companies Workit Health and SkySpecs to showcase the innovation and job creation taking place in the district.   Fast growing startup companies are not unique to places like Silicon Valley. Across the country, in areas from health care to renewable energy to education, startups are revolutionizing the way we solve problems and Southeast Michigan is leading the way. The entrepreneurs I met with today are not only creating innovative new products and services, they’re creating jobs and contributing to the local economy. In fact, 63 percent of the companies working with Ann Arbor SPARK are hiring in 2017.   Southeast Michigan is a hub for these emerging companies, and I’m committed to working with our entrepreneurs, Ann Arbor SPARK and our world-class colleges and universities to ensure we have an environment where startup companies can grow and thrive. Read more here: http://bit.ly/2uhPrM5

Mississippi Governor Phil Bryant’s attacks against the UAW International Union and collective bargaining are offensive and uncalled for. I’m proud to represent thousands of hardworking auto workers in Southeast Michigan who know the importance of a hard day’s work, and the Governor’s repeated attacks on the UAW are attacks on working families in Michigan and across the country.   We all take for granted things unions negotiated for all of us - a 40-hour work week, safe working conditions, vacation time and sick leave; student to teacher ratios and nurse to patient ratios in hospitals all came about as the result of collective negotiation. The right to collective bargaining is one of our most fundamental rights as Americans and should always be protected, not assaulted.

After months of delay, the administration has released a critical study on ways to prevent Asian carp from entering the #GreatLakes. With the discovery of a live silver carp only nine miles from Lake Michigan in June, this study should have been made public far sooner. Asian carp have the potential to decimate the waters we all love and depend upon, as well as our region’s $7 billion fishing and $16 billion boating industries.   We cannot afford to wait to combat this threat. This long-overdue study is critical to getting a full understanding of our options to stop this destructive force. We need to review its recommendations in detail and have a full and robust public comment period, then work to immediately implement measures that will ensure Asian carp never enter the Great Lakes.

Thanks to everyone who attended tonight's town hall with State Rep. Darrin Camilleri and me to discuss access to quality health care in Michigan and across the country. We need to work together under regular order to fix what’s not working in the ACA and give people peace of mind that the provisions that do work – the provisions families depend upon – are protected.

Yesterday is a sad chapter in our nation's history. Our hearts go out to the families of those who died and were injured. The fear, hatred and racism brought into Charlottesville have no place in America. We must be united against hate. United we stand, divided we fall.

The Detroit River International Wildlife Refuge is John Dingell's passion, and if you ask him, his most important accomplishment. Nolan Finley wrote a beautiful piece in the Detroit News today about the effort to save the Detroit River and establish the Refuge for future generations to enjoy.

82 years ago, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt signed Social Security into law with John Dingell, Sr. standing at his side. John's father was one of the original authors of this historic legislation and fought to protect the program throughout his career.  Social Security was created as a promise that our seniors can age with economic security and dignity after a lifetime of hard work, and years later, it continues to provide vital benefits to a growing number of Americans. With 10,000 Americans turning 65 every day, the question of how to care for our seniors grows more urgent, and it is critical that we preserve Social Security and the guarantee that it provides to the most vulnerable among us. Now more than ever, we must work together to protect and improve Social Security for seniors today and for generations to come. As Vice Chair of the Seniors Task Force, this remains one of my top priorities. #SocSec82

"Both sides" did not carry Nazi flags, drive a vehicle into innocent people or bring hatred to the streets of Charlottesville. There is no "both sides." You cannot defend any member of the KKK, neo-Nazis, or white supremacists. They are pure evil, and any person who fails to denounce it enables it.

Toured the UAW-Ford Technical Training Center today and met with leaders to discuss their one of a kind program that provides workers with the skills they need to succeed in the 21st-century economy. We need to do everything we can to address the challenges facing working American men and women, and this joint effort by the UAW and Ford is a model for how apprenticeship programs can grow opportunity for American workers and close the jobs and skills gap that workers and businesses are facing. It is my hope that similar programs are implemented across Michigan and the rest of the country.

Today's attack in Barcelona, Spain is another reminder of the presence of evil amongst us and innocent lives lost after a senseless act of terror. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families, and we stand united with our friends in Spain and across the globe in denouncing terrorism wherever it threatens freedom, democracy, and peace. We cannot let fear and hatred divide us, and instead must stand united in defeating evil in all forms.

Congress cannot stand on the sidelines as we watch this nation be divided by fear and hatred. The President of the United States has a responsibility to bring us together during challenging, difficult times and not appear to support evil in any form.  "Both sides" did not carry Nazi flags, drive a vehicle into innocent people or bring hatred to the streets of Charlottesville. There is no "both sides," and we cannot let these statements go unchallenged.  That’s why I joined 78 of my colleagues in introducing a resolution to officially censure President Trump for his remarks. It must be said loud and clear: there is no moral equivalence between the KKK, white supremacists, neo-Nazis and those standing united against them. His words did not reflect our nation’s values, and it is incumbent on all of us to fight for equality and denounce bigotry, violence and hatred in all forms. Congress must send a strong, clear signal to all of America and the world as to who we are as a nation in our resolve to treat every human being with respect, dignity and equality.

Today is Women’s Equality Day, the 97th anniversary of the adoption of the 19th Amendment, guaranteeing women the right to vote. On this anniversary, we honor the work of the courageous women and men who fought for decades to achieve this goal and celebrate the fearless women in our own lives. The work of these trailblazers has given generations of women the opportunity to follow their dreams and tear down barriers in every part of our society- whether it’s in school, on the field, in the board room, or in our military.    In recognizing the progress our society has made since the adoption of the 19th Amendment, we recommit to opening doors wider for the generations to come. We know there is no better way to strengthen our economy than by expanding economic opportunity and security for women and their families - by ensuring equal pay for equal work, providing paid sick days, encouraging paid family leave, and expanding affordable child care.   On Women’s Equality Day, let us rededicate ourselves to ensuring every woman can reach her full potential, knowing that when women succeed, our families and communities thrive.

On #LaborDay, we celebrate the contributions working men and women have made to the American economy and to the strength and well-being of our country.    In Michigan, home of the modern labor movement, we know the hard-fought victories labor won for all of us – better wages, safer working conditions, a 40-hour work week, health care and retirement benefits, safe nurse to patient ratios and classrooms that aren’t overcrowded. The battles fought and won by labor improved the well-being and standard of living not just for their members, but for all who labor. We must never take these gains for granted.   At a time when unions are undermined and under attack, we must stand in solidarity with working men and women across this country. We need to fight for policies that keep good-paying jobs in this country, grow manufacturing and level the playing field on trade; we need policies that raise wages, address income inequality and ensure that the pensions working men and women have paid into their entire working lives are protected. We will never stop working toward these goals.   Today, I march side by side with my brothers and sisters in downtown Detroit, as I have for decades. I renew my promise to fight for working men and women every single day and thank labor for what they continue to do for all of us – for all boats rise with a strong labor movement.

The reports that President Trump will end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals Program, or DACA, are heartbreaking for the individuals who came to this country as children and for the businesses, universities and communities that benefit from their contributions every day.       These young people were brought here through no fault of their own. America is their home and DACA has allowed them to become hardworking, contributing members of our society – offering their talents to the workforce and paying taxes that go toward improving our health care, infrastructure and other critical services. Regardless of whether they earn a college degree, work on a farm or in a restaurant, or are raising a family, they deserve the opportunity to apply for permanent resident status, and ultimately citizenship, and not be ripped from their families and the lives they know.  In light of these reports, Congress must come together with businesses, universities, and lawmakers of both parties to protect these individuals. This is not only the right thing for these young people, but for our country and our economic competitiveness – now and in the future.

Today, the House unanimously passed bipartisan legislation I developed in the Energy and Commerce Committee - the SELF DRIVE Act, which brings us one step closer to reshaping American innovation for generations to come. Automated vehicles have the potential to transform mobility in this country – reducing congestion on our roads, providing greater independence to seniors and those with disabilities, and helping to prevent the 35,000 deaths on our roadways each year. This is also fundamentally an issue of American competitiveness. Automated vehicles are going to be developed whether we like it or not. The question is whether the United States will remain in the driver’s seat as opposed to China, Japan, or even the EU who are all making significant investments in this space. The SELF DRIVE Act steers us in the right direction, and I want to thank the bipartisan leadership of the Energy and Commerce Committee for their hard work and support to get this legislation across the finish line.  This issue is so important for Michigan. Our state is synonymous with the development of the automobile; we transformed transportation and mobility with great inventors like Henry Ford, the Chryslers, Buick, and the Fisher brothers who all had a vision to make people's lives better. This isn't just about moving people from point A to point B, it is about human progress – the freedom of mobility to help make people's lives better and change the way the world moves. Michigan and the U.S. have always been at the forefront of this effort, and the SELF DRIVE Act will help ensure we can continue to innovate and lead for decades to come.

I am deeply disturbed by the implications of Secretary DeVos' words today on sexual assault and domestic violence. For too long survivors of assault suffered in silence, afraid to come forward for fear of retribution, or quite frankly, lack of action. I am someone who grew up in a household that was violent – where our calls for help were ignored because my father was a prominent member of the community. We cannot go back to a time when domestic violence and sexual assault were simply swept under the rug.   The implications of the Secretary's statements are chilling for survivors; we need them to know that we have their backs. I know what happened in families like mine when there was no one to help. And on college campuses, and sadly high schools as well, the reality is too many survivors suffered the consequences and were forced out of school while their attackers harmed others with impunity. We must stand strong to ensure we protect survivors of sexual violence and abuse and stand against any effort to weaken the progress made. #TitleIX

We are facing an opioid crisis in communities in Michigan and across the country. Please join Washtenaw Sheriff Jerry Clayton and I for a town hall Sunday from 6-8 p.m. to ask questions and discuss federal, state and local efforts to address the opioid epidemic, substance use disorders and other key issues. We hope to see you there.

Today we come together as Americans to remember September 11, 2001. We remember the 3,000 innocent lives lost on that horrific day and the families whose worlds changed forever. We pay tribute to the heroes - the first responders and regular citizens who rushed to the aid of their fellow Americans in New York City, Washington, DC and Shanksville, Pennsylvania. We honor and remember the men and women in uniform who courageously stepped forward to defend this nation and all it stands for.    Though this day is marked by profound pain and loss, it is also characterized by heroism and unity. Today, on the 16th anniversary, let us honor the heroes of that day. Let us remember the spirit of unity and courage with which this nation responded to this act of unconscionable evil, and let us remember the values that bind us together as Americans. #NeverForget

Proud to serve as co-chair of House Democrats' New Economy Task Force - part of a unified effort to expand economic opportunities for working Americans.   Today, every industry – from autos and manufacturing to health care and renewable energy – is changing at a rapid pace. The new economy presents challenges and opportunities, and it is critical that Congress focus on policies that will support the American worker. The New Economy Task Force will take a forward-looking approach to job growth, looking at rapidly advancing technology, artificial intelligence, advanced manufacturing, and ensuring workers are trained for the jobs of tomorrow. I look forward to working collaboratively with my colleagues, workers, business, labor and academia to ensure we are making the right investments in America’s workforce today. #JobsForAmerica

Proud to stand with AFGE, the National Wildlife Federation and the Sierra Club at today's Save the US EPA press conference to call on Congress to fully fund the EPA. The agency is facing deep cuts from President Trump and the Republican Congress that could slash up to 25 percent of the EPA workforce and endanger its ability to protect public health and the environment for decades to come. This is unacceptable.   We cannot afford to lose these jobs or halt the critical work taking place in EPA offices in Michigan and across the country. That is why I have introduced legislation called the REGION Act, which would prevent the closure of any EPA regional or program office and protect thousands of jobs. This legislation will ensure that these dedicated scientists, engineers and public servants can continue working every day to protect the air we breathe and the water we drink now and for the future. #SaveUSEPA

Deeply honored last night to be recognized as a Michiganian of the Year and to be part of a group doing so much for southeastern Michigan. Congratulations to all the winners and those who have been honored in previous years. We all share a love of our community, state and country.  Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. observed, “people fail to get along because they fear each other; they fear each other because they don't know each other; they don't know each other because they have not communicated with each other.” We need to stop this demonization of each other and work to get to know each other, listen and find the common ground so we can find solutions to the problems facing the American people. Thanks to everyone who attended last night's town hall meeting at UAW Local 600 to discuss the renegotiation of #NAFTA, and to all of our panelists who shared their valuable insight. Bad trade deals like NAFTA have devastated our region, hollowing out our manufacturing base and costing more than 60,000 Michigan jobs. We now have an opportunity to renegotiate this failed agreement, and we must do so in a way that puts working families first. Any renegotiated deal must address currency manipulation, the mother of all trade barriers, eliminate NAFTA's offshoring incentives and include strong Buy America policies to create jobs at home. I will not rest until we get a better deal for the working men and women I represent.   Thanks to Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen Global Trade Watch, Ron Bieber, President of Michigan AFL-CIO, AJ Freer, vice president of UAW Local 600, Jennifer Kelly, director of research at UAW International Union, Sue Browne, rapid response coordinator at United Steelworkers, and Adonis Flores, organizer at Michigan United for sharing your knowledge and for all you do for Michigan's working families. #ReplaceNAFTA

Secretary DeVos’ announcement is an outrageous affront to survivors of sexual assault across this country. The decision to rescind #TitleIX protections, and introduce new, less protective interim guidance before the rulemaking process has even taken place is unacceptable and turns back the clock to a time when survivors of rape and assault suffered in silence, terrified that if they came forward they would be ostracized on campus or in their classrooms, or that their voices would be ignored completely.   We must protect due process, but what we cannot do is again tip the scales of justice against survivors. This decision does exactly that – it discourages survivors from speaking out and seeking justice and sends a message that instead of support, they will be met with doubt and skepticism. This is shameful and unacceptable.
Joining Michigan State Representatives, families and health care providers to discuss local impact of the last-ditch #Trumpcare bill.

This weekend, we heard from families, health care providers and many others about what the #GrahamCassidy bill would mean for Michigan and how much is at stake. Not only does this devastating proposal end Medicaid as we know it by cutting and capping the program, it also eliminates Healthy Michigan and completely eviscerates protections for people with pre-existing conditions, including autism, asthma and even pregnancy. This is unacceptable. We should be working together on productive, bipartisan action to stabilize the insurance marketplaces and extend affordable health care coverage to more families, not ramming through devastating proposals that take it away. We will continue to working to #ProtectOurCare and stand against this devastating bill that will hurt families in our state.  Thank you to everyone who participated this weekend, including Linda Atkins, CEO of Western Wayne Family Health Centers, who hosted us for this important event; Laura Appel of the Michigan Health & Hospital Association; Farah Erzouki of ACCESS; State Reps. Darrin Quiroz Camilleri, Cara Clemente and State Representative Erika Geiss; and Alexis Wyatt of Brownstown and Kari Snyder of Wyandotte who courageously shared their stories. Please read more about what Graham-Cassidy would mean for their families and for Michigan below.

Pleased to join First Lady Sue Snyder's "Let's End Campus Sexual Assault" Summit today to help inform our communities, empower survivors and ultimately end sexual assault on campus. An estimated one in five women has been sexually assaulted during her college years, and that's not a trend we can accept in Michigan or across the country. With Title IX protections being rolled back at schools nationwide, it is more critical than ever that we come together to protect survivors and ensure we don’t go back to a time when sexual assault was a secret that was swept under the rug. Michigan can, and should, lead on this issue, and I will work with the First Lady, our universities, state representatives and all members of our communities on bipartisan solutions that make our campuses safer. #MISaferCampus

Eastern Michigan University sponsored their first “Out of the Darkness Community Walk” today to help raise awareness about issues surrounding suicide and mental health. September is Suicide Prevention Month, and with it comes the question of how we as a community can help end the stigma associated with mental health and bring conversations about suicide out of the darkness once and for all. The campus lost one of their own in the last week. Far too many families have suffered the heartbreak of suicide. With this year’s Suicide Prevention Month theme, “Take a Minute, Change a Life,” we are reminded of the actions that each of us can can take, however small, to educate others, touch someone and support our family, friends and community. While difficult to speak about, it is the reason I share my own family's story to help remove the stigma of talking about it.  I was also with veterans today and we need to remember our veterans are disproportionately impacted by suicide. The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs has enacted the #BeThere program to help combat this statistic and support veterans and servicemembers.  Small actions, like checking in on a neighbor or even a friendly smile can mean more than you know and help make someone feel less alone. We must continue to talk about these difficult issues, raise awareness and provide support. I told everyone today hug someone every day that just looks like they need someone to show they care. It is my hope that in doing so, we can help one another heal and reclaim hope.   National Suicide Prevention Hotline: 1-800-273-8255  Veterans Crisis Line: 1-800-273-8255

I am deeply disturbed by reports that nearly a quarter of Michigan's nursing homes have been cited for serious health and safety violations, including instances of actual harm to residents. This is unacceptable. Families, seniors and those with disabilities who rely on these facilities deserve confidence in knowing that they will be safe and treated with care and respect. We cannot settle for anything less, and I will be looking at what role the federal government can and should play to ensure quality of care at these facilities, which serve our most vulnerable.

Our nation awoke to horror as we learned that more than 50 innocent people lost their lives and hundreds more were injured in the deadliest mass shooting in our country’s history. Our hearts are with Las Vegas, those fallen and injured, their families and all affected by this unimaginable violence. May they find comfort in knowing that our nation stands with them and grieves alongside them.   We cannot allow fear or violence to divide us or change us. We must stand together and work together to prevent another act of cowardice from stealing innocent lives.

Left with more questions than answers today after questioning former Equifax Chairman and CEO Richard Smith on the massive data breach that impacted more than 140 million Americans. It is critical that the American people can educate themselves about who has their data, how it is being used, and take reasonable steps to secure their identity and information.   Most people had no idea that Equifax was even holding their data. It’s one thing to take steps to mitigate damages after a breach has occurred, but going forward we must give consumers the chance to protect themselves before a breach happens. We need a longer debate about who owns this data and how we educate the American people.  We also need action, which is why I introduced the Data Protection Act of 2017 to require companies to better secure consumers’ sensitive personal information against a potential security breach. I am also a cosponsor of the Secure and Protect Americans’ Data Act, introduced by Energy and Commerce Ranking Member Frank Pallone and Rep. Schakowsky. We must raise the bar for companies that store sensitive personal information. It is critical that we take action on the topic and that all American consumers pay attention.

Despite 6.8 million Americans currently seeking jobs in the U.S., a recent survey by the National Federation of Independent Business found that 45 percent of small business owners said they were unable to find qualified applicants to fill job openings.   As co-chair of the New Economy Task Force, I'm working with my colleagues to discover new ways of closing our nation's skills gap. Today, I sent a letter to community colleges in Michigan and across the country to learn how these vital institutions are addressing the disparities between existing workforce skills and the skills sought by companies for the jobs of tomorrow.   Our community colleges are on the front lines of innovation. Students are learning to repair the engine of an airplane and protect against cyber attacks, and are being trained to enter vital skilled trades careers like welding, carpentry, plumbing and pipefitting. With the economy changing at a rapid pace, hearing from our nation's community colleges will help inform our work to develop policies that will ensure the U.S. can compete in the 21st century global economy and ensure everyone who wants a good job can find one and provide for their families. #JobsForAmerica

Here we are again playing politics with working men and women's lives. Tonight, the House Energy and Commerce Committee considered Republican proposals that would reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and community health centers by slashing billions from Medicare and the Affordable Care Act. CHIP is a lifeline for nearly nine million American children, ensuring that every child can go to the doctor when they need to and have necessary check-ups, immunizations and medical treatment. Community health centers fill the gaps in our system and are the main point of care for many Americans who have nowhere else to turn. These critical programs have been bipartisan from day one and should continue to be just that.  We have a responsibility to provide care for all Americans – young, old, sick, healthy, rich and poor. It is part of our fabric as a nation. We should not be robbing Peter to pay Paul, or in this case, dealing a devastating blow to the Affordable Care Act, Medicare and the seniors who depend on it in order to pay for equally important priorities.  I won't take a back seat to anybody in terms of fighting for children and working families. In Michigan, we have 82,000 kids on CHIP and another 1.2 million on Medicaid. If we don't act soon, Michigan will soon start to send notices to families that their child's coverage could be cancelled.  Imagine being single, working mother who is working two jobs to make ends meet, coming home after a very long day of work to find a letter saying your child may not have health insurance in a few weeks. You think about cutting back on groceries, keeping the house even colder, doing without medicine for yourself. This could be a reality for families in our state.  What we considered today doesn't work and is simply unacceptable. The authorization for these programs has already expired and we must act now, which is why it is so disappointing that this Republican proposal forces a false choice between kids and seniors. We should not undermine Medicare to pay for CHIP. Similarly, we should not raid $10 billion from the Affordable Care Act, including from the Prevention and Public Health Fund which provided critical aid in response to the Flint water crisis, to reauthorize our vital community health centers.   We should take a deep breath and move forward with consensus legislation that reauthorizes CHIP and community health centers rather than the dangerous and misguided proposals put forward today that put our children, families and seniors at risk.

Manufacturing continues to be the backbone of the U.S. economy, and it is at the heart and soul of who we are in Michigan. Our state has been the home of every major auto company in this country for over a century and that remains true today. The hardworking men and women of the American auto industry have helped transform the automobile from the Model-T to the Taurus and now to some of the most fuel efficient vehicles on the market.   Michigan’s manufacturing story is really a story of innovation – and whether it’s building cars or developing next-generation drone technology, we continue to be on the cutting edge. Today we honor the working men and women of the American manufacturing sector who make the greatest products in the world. Today is also about continuing this legacy and showing young people what modern manufacturing really looks like. Nearly 3,000 manufacturing centers around the country will open their doors to students, educators and families to help inspire our next generation to fill the 3.5 million jobs manufacturers will create. This is critical to ensuring we continue to grow manufacturing, create good-paying jobs and ensure the U.S. leads in the 21st century global economy.

An important conversation happening today at 6 p.m. at Huron High School. Join Washtenaw Sheriff Jerry Clayton and an excellent group of panelists to ask questions and receive updates on efforts to address the opioid epidemic, substance use disorders, and other key issues. This town hall, the third in a series, will specifically focus on how mental health, substance use and the opioid crisis are impacting young people in Washtenaw County.  It is critical that we come together as a community to learn, provide input, and discuss how we can address this crisis, which is impacting too many of our families. Today on International #Dayofthegirl we recommit to ensuring girls everywhere can reach their full potential. It was an honor to join the Canadian Embassy, Together for Girls, USAID - US Agency for International Development, UNWOMEN and many others to highlight, discuss, take action and commit to being part of a solution.   Around the world, at least one in every three women has been beaten, coerced into sex, or otherwise abused in her lifetime. Data from the Together for Girls partnership shows that more than one in four girls’ first sexual experience is forced or coerced. This has severe consequences for her mental and physical well-being throughout her life.   We must break the cycle of violence against women and girls, and the U.S. must play a leading role. Leadership must start here at home - whether it is continuing critical Title IX guidelines that protect survivors of sexual assault in K-12 schools and on college campuses, or ensuring full funding for vital programs that improve the lives of girls around the world. When women and girls can live safely, free from violence and discrimination, our families and communities thrive.

Proud to introduce the Vehicle Innovation Act today to promote investments in research and development of clean vehicle technologies. Michigan's auto industry has made major advancements in cutting-edge fuel efficiency technologies in the last decade. This legislation builds on the progress made by investing in successful research programs that will help improve vehicle efficiency – saving consumers money at the pump, improving energy security and keeping the U.S. and southeast Michigan at the forefront of vehicle innovation.

This executive order is the most extreme and blatant attempt yet to undermine and sabotage the Affordable Care Act and cause instability in the marketplace. Under the President’s plan, insurers will once again be allowed to offer junk policies that provide no coverage at all, taking us back to a time when Americans were one serious illness or injury away from bankruptcy.   The American people are demanding real solutions to the challenges facing our health care system. Rather than increasing costs and gutting protections for those with pre-existing conditions, President Trump and Congressional Republicans should come together with Democrats to stabilize the marketplace, bring down costs and extend quality, affordable coverage to more families. This is what the American people demand and it is what they deserve.

It is disappointing to hear that Attorney General Bill Schuette will not join over 20 states in filing a lawsuit to keep the critical cost-sharing reduction subsidies that directly lower out-of-pocket health care costs for those who need it most. 177,000 people in Michigan received CSR's in 2016 which represents 51% of statewide enrollment. President Trump's decision to revoke these payments will immediately result in increased costs for many in our state and across the country. We need to know exactly where our Attorney General stands and whether he believes every Michigander deserves access to quality, affordable health care. We need to help reassure people who are scared for what this means for their family that they will be able to get the medical attention they need if they get sick. Does Bill Schuette think that is wrong?

We did it! Today a diverse group of approximately 3755 women, from six weeks to 110 years old, came together from Michigan and all over the world to help preserve our state's history and bring the Rosie record home. This was an incredible afternoon with all generations – including 58 Original Rosies – sharing stories, passing on our history and celebrating the iconic women who stepped up during World War II and forever transformed the role of women in the workplace. We were united as Americans and celebrating how everyone came together in this country at that historical time. These trailblazing women continue to inspire and empower us all, and reclaiming the world record is a perfect tribute to their enduring legacy and ‘We Can Do It’ spirit. Today we are all prouder than ever of the amazing story we represent.

Spent a perfect fall weekend in Michigan at many community gatherings and events including the Ford Hispanic Network’s Annual Heritage Celebration in Dearborn, the Van Buren Township Fire Department's pancake breakfast, the American Cancer Society Making Strides against Breast Cancer walk in Ann Arbor, the Downriver National Suicide Prevention Walk and many more. A highlight of the weekend was joining over 3,755 women and girls on Saturday to break the world record for the largest gathering of Rosie the Riveters since World War II. 58 original Rosies were in attendance and inspired all of us with their stories and enduring spirit. There is nothing better than a weekend spent with old friends and new ones, and I am looking forward to many more important discussions and events during this week’s District Work Period.

We know here in Michigan that Medicaid is a lifeline for seniors, children and people with disabilities. Medicaid covers 2.3 million adults and children in our state, including 700,000 Michiganders who are covered by Healthy Michigan through the Affordable Care Act. The Administration’s relentless assault on the ACA and Medicaid puts the health coverage that our most vulnerable populations depend upon at risk. This is unacceptable.  We’ve been able to stop these dangerous proposals so far because the American people stood up and spoke with a unified voice. But we must remain vigilant. We have to keep fighting, and that is why conversations like this are so important. Together we will keep telling our story about why Medicaid matters in Michigan and across the country and protect this vital program that is a lifeline for many.

Today, during Domestic Violence Awareness Month, we launched a new regional coalition aimed at ending domestic violence in our communities. This coalition brings together local domestic violence organizations, health care providers, resource centers, advocacy groups, law enforcement and elected officials to join forces and work together to prevent domestic violence and improve support for survivors. We know that when we all work together we can do more to create communities without violence. I look forward to working with this coalition in the weeks and months ahead on comprehensive solutions that protect and empower survivors.

Today we came together in the House – Democrats and Republicans – to remind people that October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month.  One in eight women will get breast cancer in her lifetime. On average, a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer every two minutes, and many of us have a mother, grandmother, daughter, aunt, sister or friend who has been impacted. We’ve made progress over the last couple of decades with early detection and improved treatments, but much work remains. This month, we come together to support survivors, remind women and men of the importance of self-exams and mammograms, to stand with those fighting this horrible disease and recommit ourselves to finding a cure to end breast cancer once and for all.

After holding a series of community town halls on the opioid epidemic, I relayed the concerns shared with me by constituents to witnesses at our Energy and Commerce Committee hearing on federal efforts to combat the crisis. I pressed the commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration on what is being done to understand pain and its management, and to develop new products to treat pain without addiction and to treat recovering addicts.   The opioid epidemic is a complicated, multifaceted problem without a single solution. I have lived on both sides of the issue. Growing up, my father abused prescription drugs and my sister ultimately lost her battle with addiction and died of a drug overdose. I also live with a man who suffers from chronic pain and needs access to opioids to manage it. We cannot let the pendulum swing too far in either direction. We must take real, serious steps to stop the number of overdoses in our country while still ensuring patients can access the medicine they need.

The American people deserve a budget that puts them first – that invests in good-paying jobs, grows wages, and invests in the promise of a secure and healthy retirement. The Republican budget resolution that passed the House today fails this test. It proposes to slash $1 trillion from Medicaid, which provides critical long-term care for seniors, and nearly $500 billion from Medicare, ending the program as we know it at a time when 10,000 seniors turn 65 every day. This proposal would also slash investments in education, job-training and infrastructure programs, which create jobs and help working families compete and succeed, and increase the deficit by more than $1 trillion – all to pave the way for a tax reform plan that provides a massive tax break to the wealthy and big corporations instead of the working families who need it most.   This is not responsible budgeting or responsible governing. Democrats fully support tax reform that helps working families succeed, promotes economic growth and makes the tax code simpler and fairer. We are ready and willing to work with Republicans toward that goal, but we cannot support a budget that cuts taxes for the wealthy on the backs of hardworking Americans, seniors and children.

These latest revelations are deeply disturbing. Michiganders deserve accurate information about the quality and condition of the pipelines, which carry 23 million gallons of oil through the Straits of Mackinac every day. Enbridge has repeatedly failed to disclose damage and potential vulnerabilities to Line 5 in a timely manner. This is unacceptable, and why Congressman Dave Trott and I have introduced legislation to ensure a comprehensive study of the pipelines. If Line 5 is found to be unsafe, it should be shut down.

For details about available plans visit www.HealthCare.gov or call 1-800-318-2596. Open Enrollment is shorter this year than in the past, so don't wait to learn about your options and #GetCovered for 2018!

Working Americans should be at the heart of #TaxReform. Families in Michigan and across the country are looking to Congress to enact tax reform that provides real relief for childcare and education expenses, makes homeownership affordable and accessible and promotes retirement security. Instead, the GOP tax plan released today gives a multi-trillion dollar tax break to the wealthy and big corporations at the expense of working Americans who need it most.  Particularly concerning is that this tax reform bill represents a one-two punch for the American people. After adding trillions to the debt in tax breaks for the wealthy, this plan paves the way for devastating cuts to Medicare, Medicaid and the programs families, children and seniors depend upon for health care and retirement security. This is unacceptable. Democrats fully support tax reform that puts working families first, promotes economic growth and makes our tax code simpler and fairer, but I will not support tax reform that adds $1.5 trillion to the deficit only to benefit the wealthy. Working families must benefit.

The legislation we considered today represents a choice that we should not have to make. When it comes to fighting for children and families, I will take a backseat to no one – it is the reason I ran for office. We live in the United States of America, the greatest nation in the world, and I reject the notion that we have to rob Peter to pay Paul – or in this instance jeopardize the future of Medicare and steal $6 billion from critical prevention programs seniors, children and families rely upon to pay for the Children’s Health Insurance Program. #CHIP has always been bipartisan, and there is no reason that cannot be true today. We have a responsibility to provide care for all Americans – young, old, sick, healthy, rich and poor. We should not be providing health care for some at the expense of others.  The time for political games is over. CHIP is a lifeline for nearly 9 million American children, ensuring that every child can go to the doctor when they need to and have necessary checkups, immunizations and medical treatment. The program has already expired for more than a month, and the 100,000 children in Michigan who benefit from it now have their coverage in jeopardy because we are here playing games. Enough is enough. This is not an academic debate – this is about people’s lives. CHIP has always been strongly bipartisan, and we should be working together on consensus legislation that provides children and their families with certainty that they will have the care they need when their child gets sick; not this misguided proposal that puts our children, families and seniors at risk.

Today I introduced legislation to secure America's voting systems against foreign interference by providing states with the information, intelligence and resources needed to protect electronic voting systems from manipulation and hacking, and to update aging infrastructure.   Our democracy depends on free and fair elections, and we must do everything we can to protect the security and integrity of that process. The reality is, many of our voting machines have not been updated in nearly two decades and are susceptible to cyberattacks. We know that foreign adversaries pay very close attention to our elections, and until we address these vulnerabilities, our democratic process is at risk. This legislation ensures states have the resources and intelligence necessary to protect voting equipment and safeguard our elections from outside interference.

Veterans Day is the day we pause to salute the men and women who have served our country and defended the ideals that make this nation great. We remember, honor and thank those who answered the call to serve in Europe and the Pacific during World War II, those who defended the 38th parallel in Korea, braved the jungles of Vietnam, fought in the deserts of Iraq and the mountains of Afghanistan, and those still standing up for democracy around the world. These courageous men and women have spent time away from their families – they’ve missed birthdays and holidays, and many have made the ultimate sacrifice, to protect our freedoms and way of life. We are forever grateful for their service and sacrifice.  Today, as we honor our veterans, we remember the words of President John F. Kennedy, ‘As we express our gratitude, we must never forget that the highest appreciation is not to utter words, but to live by them.’ Today, let it be our pledge that we will serve our veterans as well as they served us – with timely, quality health care, good-paying jobs, prompt benefits, and a roof over their heads when they come home. Let us all take a moment, not just today, but every day, to thank the veterans in our own communities, to remember those we have lost, those still serving around the world and the military families who serve and sacrifice alongside them. They have given us so much, and it is because of them that we proudly remain the land of the free and the home of the brave.

Joined colleagues, students, seniors and working families today to rally against the flawed Republican tax plan that puts the wealthy and big corporations ahead of working families. We need a tax plan that puts working families first – that provides real relief for childcare expenses and student debt, promotes retirement security and protects vital deductions relied on by families with sick children and those with long-term care needs.   Instead, this plan asks working families to sacrifice more so multinational corporations and the wealthiest can get a tax cut – all while paving the way for future cuts to Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. Proud to join colleagues, members of the Teamsters, the United Mine Workers of America and their families today to announce legislation that will ensure retirees in Michigan and across the country receive the #pensions they have earned.  This legislation will bring relief to the tens of thousands of workers and retirees whose lives have been turned upside down by proposed cuts to their pensions. The working men and women I represent earned these pensions over a lifetime of labor and commitment. This is the money they counted on to retire with dignity and security – to afford to stay in their homes and afford their medicine – and we must do everything we can to ensure they have the benefits they have earned. It is critical that we advance this bill through the Congress this year.   American workers have done their part, now it’s time for Congress to do ours.

This week, more than 73 years after his plane crashed in World War II, Second Lieutenant Donald Underwood's remains are being returned home to his family in Michigan. This is a time of joy, gratitude for Lt. Underwood's service to our country, and closure for his family, who never gave up hope. It was an honor to work alongside them - his brother George and his son-in-law Mike Mehall, as well as the non-profit organization History Flight - to locate, recover and identify Lt. Underwood's remains so they could be returned to his family. He will receive a hero's burial at Arlington National Cemetery next week.   It is my hope that this story will bring hope to all families who are waiting for someone they love to return home. As we approach the Thanksgiving holiday, let us keep in our hearts and minds the men and women in uniform still missing in action, prisoners of war, and the individuals who have sacrificed so much in defense of this nation. We must never forget them and we must never forget their families.

Wishing you all a happy Thanksgiving filled with family, friendship, love and gratitude. As we gather together to give thanks for the many blessings in our lives, may we remember our servicemembers, veterans and their families, who have sacrificed so much to keep us safe and free. Let us also take time this Thanksgiving holiday to remember that despite our differences, we are all one community, united by love for the country we all share. From our family to yours, we wish you a happy and healthy Thanksgiving.

Today's agreement between the state and Enbridge is a beginning toward safeguarding the #GreatLakes and protecting the drinking water that 40 million people rely upon. The Line 5 pipeline carries twenty-three million gallons of oil through the Straits of Mackinac every day. A spill in this area would be devastating for the Great Lakes ecosystem, economy and our way of life, and that is a risk we cannot afford to take.   Enbridge has repeatedly failed to disclose potential vulnerabilities to this pipeline, and this agreement will help hold the company to account, ensure the public is informed and that critical safety standards are in place. While this is an important step, I continue to believe that if a comprehensive study of the pipelines finds Line 5 to be unsafe, it should be shut down.

The Republican tax bill being rushed through Congress is increasingly benefiting the wealthy and big corporations at the expense of everyone else. According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, the Senate tax bill would negatively impact workers earning less than $30,000 a year by 2019, and increase taxes for those earning $75,000 and below in the next 10 years. This is unacceptable. The American people deserve tax reform that puts them first. This bill fails that test, and it must be defeated.

Targeting and profiling people because of their faith stands against every principle our nation was founded on. I represent Muslim Americans who are our friends, neighbors, teachers, doctors, valued community leaders and very patriotic Americans. The President of the United States should not be reinforcing individuals or groups that are trying to divide us with fear and hatred. We all need to remember – united we stand, divided we fall.

Proud that the House approved bipartisan legislation today to reauthorize EPA's Brownfields program, which has helped to clean up contaminated and hazardous sites in our district and turn them into assets for the community. In 2013, the Downriver Community Conference received Brownfields funding to clear out asbestos and other hazardous materials from a hangar at Willow Run Airport. Today this site, once the home of the Arsenal of Democracy and the original Rosie the Riveters during World War II, is now the home of the American Center for Mobility—a national DOT proving ground for the testing and validation of connected and automated vehicles. There are many success stories in Michigan and across this country that would not be possible without Brownfields grant funding, and this legislation will ensure this critical work continues.

From working to ensure every child has the opportunity to receive a quality education to ensuring workers can compete on a level playing field, Michigan is undoubtedly better and stronger because of Rep. The Supreme Court’s decision to allow President Trump’s Muslim ban to go into effect while legal challenges continue in the lower courts is extremely disappointing. Freedom of religion is a fundamental pillar of our Constitution, and the President’s executive order represents a thinly veiled ban on entry to this country based on religion. This hateful action will keep people apart from their loved ones, and as national security experts have warned, make our country less safe. It goes against everything our nation stands for, and we will continue to fight against these efforts to divide us.

Today, I introduced bipartisan legislation with my colleague Congressman Daniel Webster to strengthen and evaluate worst-case scenario preparedness for hospitals and long-term care facilities. Emergency preparedness policies at our nation’s hospitals have been seriously tried and tested this year. The destruction wrought in the paths of Hurricane Harvey, Irma, Maria and Nate left hospitals and long-term care facilities without power, flooded or shutdown, resulting in tragic loss of life.   In the face of these extreme weather threats, it is critical that emergency preparedness procedures across all medical facilities be reviewed. This legislation takes a proactive approach to identify new polices that better address future threats – both man-made and natural – so we can better protect patients. Read more here:

On Capitol Hill today working on many issues - from keeping the government open to DACA and the Children's Health Insurance Program. One issue that is overshadowed in all of this is the environment. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt is testifying before the Energy and Commerce Committee today. I'm planning to ask him about many of the issues we care about in Michigan, including keeping the #GreatLakes clean and keeping our commitment to Flint families. If you've got questions for the Administrator, please post them in the comments below and I will do my best to include them this afternoon.

Thank you for all your questions and feedback today on our Energy & Commerce hearing with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt. We had an in-depth exchange on a number of issues that matter to us. I pressed the Administrator on EPA’s proposed budget cuts to grants that support lead removal programs, the urgent need to update the Lead and Copper Rule for drinking water systems, and his proposal to eliminate funding for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative.   I am pleased that the Administrator committed to keeping the National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory open in Ann Arbor. This is so important. The more than 400 dedicated employees at the Ann Arbor EPA Lab do critical work for every single state on automotive emissions and fuel economy. This work is vital to public health, the environment and our future economic competitiveness, and I am pleased that Administrator Pruitt has now recognized the incredible value this lab provides our country. It is because of the good work and dedicated advocacy of men and women of the Ann Arbor EPA Lab and the AFGE that we are able to keep this lab open and ensure this critical work continues.

Today, I led a letter with my colleagues Congressman Don Beyer, Raul M. Grijalva and 104 Members of Congress urging House Leadership to remove harmful provisions attached to the final spending legislation for FY 18 that would weaken the #EndangeredSpeciesAct. The ESA is among the most effective laws protecting the land and wildlife the American people care about. Efforts to roll back these protections have no place in unrelated legislation to keep the government open, and must be rejected. We should be working together to improve conservation in this country, not rolling back the clock.

In Michigan, we understand the importance of investing in clean energy technologies that decrease pollution, reduce our dependence on foreign oil and keep the U.S. at the forefront of innovation. Electric vehicles exemplify the economic and environmental advantages that come with these new technologies, and I am proud that so much of the groundbreaking work to research and develop them is taking place in our state.   Our next challenge is to accelerate the adoption of fully electric cars, and that starts with making real investments in the infrastructure that supports their deployment and keeping the critical EV tax credit. We must ensure that Michigan continues to lead in this area, and I am committed to working with all stakeholders to achieve that goal.

Working families should be at the center of any effort to update our tax code. Instead, the legislation that passed the House today leaves working Americans behind – increasing taxes for 86 million families and jeopardizing the future of Medicare and Social Security, all while providing trillions in tax breaks to the wealthy and big corporations. This is plain wrong.   Republicans are trying to sell working families a bag of goods, but the American people will not be fooled. Those Representatives who voted today to put politics above the people they represent will have to answer to hardworking families across the country who will see their taxes go up as a result of this devastating plan. Working families deserve better, and now more than ever, we must continue to fight alongside them.

In the past few months, families across the country have received notices that their child’s health insurance will be canceled because Congress has failed to reauthorize the Children's Health Insurance Program, a lifeline for nearly nine million American children. That threat just became more real with today’s announcement that Michigan’s #CHIP allotment will expire in April 2018 and cancellation notices will start going out in the New Year to 100,000 Michigan families.   It is unconscionable that Congress would add $2.3 trillion to the deficit in order to pass tax breaks for the wealthiest and big corporations while leaving children and families out in the cold. CHIP ensures every child can go to the doctor when they need to and receive necessary checkups and immunizations. It has always been bipartisan, and there is no reason it should not be today. This is not a time for games; this is about real people’s lives. I am calling on Republican leadership to come together with Democrats to renew CHIP in a bipartisan way before we go home for Christmas. American families cannot wait any longer.

Congress has once again kicked the can down the road, passing a stop-gap bill that only funds the government for one month. It does nothing to provide certainty to businesses or families, and it does nothing to address urgent, overdue priorities for the American people. This bill fails to provide long-term funding for the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which is a lifeline for 100,000 Michigan children; it fails to address DACA and bring needed relief to the 800,000 young people who call this country home; and it fails to include a common-sense fix to put our nation’s pension plans back on solid footing so American workers can keep the retirement they have earned.    This short-term bill is a disappointing yet unsurprising way to end the year given that Republicans have spent the majority of 2017 working to rip health care away from the American people and push through a partisan tax bill that provides tax cuts to the wealthy at the expense of everyone else. Democrats remain committed to fighting for the priorities that matter to families and communities. This irresponsible plan does not live up to our responsibility as legislators, and I could not support it.

Our fish and wildlife are among our nation's most valuable resources - supporting our economy in Michigan, creating jobs and providing countless hours of outdoor enjoyment. I'm proud to introduce the bipartisan Recovering America's Wildlife Act with my colleague from Nebraska Congressman Jeff Fortenberry to help enhance our nation’s conservation efforts and ensure the long-term health of fish and wildlife throughout the country.   This legislation dedicates existing revenue from oil and gas royalties to the Wildlife Conservation Restoration Program, which would provide states with new critically needed resources to effectively implement State Wildlife Action Plans to conserve 12,000 species in greatest need of conservation while providing the public with more access to open spaces.  I'm proud to partner with Rep. Fortenberry and the National Wildlife Federation, Bass Pro Shops, the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies, the Congressional Sportsmen's Foundation and many others on this important legislation. We know we must work hard to protect our natural resources, and together we believe we can help bring conservation into the 21st Century and complement the other successful programs that are currently in place. Among the highlights of 2017 for southeast Michigan is the recent opening of the state-of-the-art American Center for Mobility at Willow Run. This world-class testing center is already bringing together automakers, suppliers, and some of the greatest minds in research to transform the future of #mobility, save lives on the road and keep Michigan at the forefront of innovation and technology. I've been proud to be part of the effort to make this center a reality, and am pleased that we were able to pass bipartisan legislation in the House, the SELF DRIVE Act, to support the development of automated vehicle technologies. This is about improving safety, supporting the auto industry’s comeback, and helping to create more cutting-edge jobs in our state. The American Center for Mobility will help keep Michigan in the driver's seat for decades to come as we transform the Arsenal of Democracy into the Arsenal of Innovation.
